entry.title: Appellate judges side with Google in anti-Muslim film case

entry.title: Appeals court sides with Google in anti-Muslim film case

entry.title: Google backed over anti-Muslim film
entry.summary:
The 9th US Circuit Court of Appeal sided with Google, which owns YouTube, after free speech advocates urged the court to overturn a 2-1 decision by three of its judges.

Google argued Garcia had no claim to the film because the film-maker wrote the dialogue, managed the production and dubbed over her lines.

entry.title: Google?s self-driving cars to begin testing? with drivers

entry.title: Google versus Oracle case exposes differences within Obama administration
entry.summary: "Google's argument - that the code lost all copyright protection because it became popular and Google wanted Android to be popular, too - would not fly for any other work," Oracle's attorneys wrote.

entry.title: Google versus Oracle case exposes differences within Obama administration
entry.summary:
Oracle won a federal appeals court ruling last year that allows it to copyright parts of Java, while Google argues it should be free to use Java without paying a licensing fee.

Google, which used Java to design its Android smartphone operating system, appealed to the U.S. Supreme Court.

According to Google, an Oracle victory would obstruct "an enormous amount of innovation" because software developers would not be able to freely build on each others' work.

Google's Android operating system is the world's best-selling smartphone platform.

Oracle sued Google in 2010, claiming that Google had improperly incorporated parts of Java into Android.

entry.title: Latest self-driving Google car heading to public streets
entry.summary: In this May 13, 2015 photo, Google's new self-driving prototype car drives around a parking lot during a demonstration at Google campus in Mountain View, Calif.

entry.title: Latest self-driving Google car heading to public streets
entry.summary: Urmson says Google needs to do a better job of educating people about self-driving technology and updating them on Google's progress.

entry.title: Latest self-driving Google car heading to public streets
entry.summary: Dmitri Dolgov, the head of software for the self-driving car project, says Google's software has gotten much better over the last year at classifying objects, like trees and mailboxes, and predicting behavior of pedestrians and other cars.

entry.title: Latest self-driving Google car heading to public streets
Google?s two-seater driverless car to hit public roads this summer
entry.summary:
This prototype is the first vehicle built from scratch for the purpose of self-driving, Google says.

It has more capabilities than the prototype Google introduced last May, which was so rudimentary it had fake headlights.

And the pod can only drive in areas that have been thoroughly mapped by Google.

But Google is lobbying for more flexible regulations.

entry.title: Uber poaches Whetstone from Google

entry.summary: Now, when a restaurant shows up in Google's search results on your phone, you can place an order with one of six different restaurant middlemen right away.

entry.title: As self-driving cars arrive, liability an issue; Google acknowledges 11 accidents in 6 years
entry.summary:
LOS ANGELES - The self-driving cars that Google Inc. has been testing on California's roads and highways were involved in 11 minor accidents over the past six years, according to the tech giant.

It was not possible to independently verify Google's assertions about the fault and nature of the collisions.

An accident caused by a self-driving car is a fear of the people developing them, whether at Google or one of the traditional automakers.

entry.title: Google acknowledges 11 accidents with its self-driving cars
entry.summary:
Google's Chris Urmson (right) shows a Google self-driving car to U.S. Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx (L) and Google Chairman Eric Schmidt (C) at the Google headquarters on February 2, 2015 in Mountain View, California.

The Google cars have been rear-ended seven times, often when stopped "but also on the freeway," wrote Urmson, director of Google's self-driving car program.

entry.title: Google acknowledges 11 accidents with its self-driving cars
entry.summary: "Cause" is a key word: Like Delphi Automotive, a parts supplier which suffered an accident in October with one of its two test cars, Google says it was not at fault.

entry.title: Google acknowledges 11 accidents with its self-driving cars
entry.summary: "Not once was the self-driving car the cause of the accident," wrote Google's Chris Urmson.

entry.title: Google acknowledges 11 accidents with its self-driving cars
entry.summary:
Google, which has been developing autonomous car technology and lobbying for the legislation has a fleet of driverless cars that has logged more than 300,000 miles of self-driving on California roads.

Google co-founder Sergey listens to California Gov. Edmund G Brown Jr. during a bill signing for driverless cars at Google headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., Tuesday, Sept.

People look at camera on top of a Google self-driving car at the Google headquarters on September 25, 2012 in Mountain View, California.

entry.title: Google acknowledges 11 accidents with its self-driving cars

Three accidents involved Lexus SUVs run by Google Inc. The fourth was an Audi retrofitted by the parts supplier Delphi Automotive.

entry.title: Google acknowledges 11 accidents with its self-driving cars
entry.summary: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Google Inc. says its self-driving cars have been in 11 minor traffic accidents since it began experimenting with the technology six years ago.

entry.title: Google tractor-beams Star Wars universe into Knowledge Graph
entry.summary: After typing, "Who is Luke's father?" for example, Google now presents the answer, Darth Vader, in a box that offers a short summary with clickable links for more information.

entry.title: Google tractor-beams Star Wars universe into Knowledge Graph
entry.summary: The search engine and the Lucasfilm movie franchise said Monday they have put information from the Star Wars universe into Google's Knowledge Graph, the first time for a fictional universe.

entry.title: Google is starting small, thinking big with 'Project Fi'
entry.summary: Here are some key things to know about Project Fi culled from a recent interview with Fox at Google's Mountain View, California, headquarters.

entry.title: Google is starting small, thinking big with 'Project Fi'
entry.summary:
In this April 24, 2015 photo, Nick Fox, Vice President for Communications Products at Google, prepares a presentation on Project Fi, in Mountain View, Calif.

Project Fi is Google's recently launched attempt to usher in new ways to keep smartphones online while lowering the cost for streaming video, listening to music, getting directions and searching for information.

entry.title: Google is starting small, thinking big with 'Project Fi'
entry.summary:
"Wireless connectivity has become so essential that it's kind of like our lifeblood," says Nick Fox, the Google Inc. executive overseeing Project Fi.

In a break from the status quo, Project Fi will cost just $20 for basic service and then only charge for the amount of data consumed over cellular networks that Google is leasing from T-Mobile and Sprint.

Google, though, is hoping Project Fi reshapes the market.

entry.title: Google is starting small, thinking big with 'Project Fi'
entry.summary:
Google's service is also promising to automatically switch customers to publicly available Wi-Fi networks to avoid incurring charges for using data on the cellular networks.

Getting on the wireless service requires a Nexus 6 smartphone, a model made by Motorola for Google as a showcase for how it would like its services to work with its Android operating system.

entry.title: Google embeds engineers as professors
entry.summary: Google software engineer and Google In Residence Sabrina Williams talks with students during a Google Student Development class on Impostor Syndrome at Howard University in Washington, Tuesday, April 14, 2015.

entry.title: Google embeds engineers as professors
entry.summary:
Legrand Burge, who chairs Howard University's computer science department, welcomes the temporary addition of Google engineers to his faculty.

Williams had 70 students in one class; about 250 were taught so far this year by Google engineers at all five schools.

This time, he said, Google is bringing a disruptive, Silicon Valley mentality to their campus.

entry.title: Google embeds engineers as professors
entry.summary: In ongoing efforts to diversify Silicon Valley's tech sector, Google is embedding engineers at a handful of Historically Black Colleges and Universities where they teach, mentor and advise on curriculum.

entry.title: Google embeds engineers as professors
entry.summary:
Google decided to go to the source, sending a handful of software engineers to teach at Howard, Hampton University in Hampton, Virginia, Fisk University in Nashville, and Spelman and Morehouse colleges in Atlanta.

Hocutt said the Google In Residence professors convinced him to apply.

Nearly 2 percent of messages sent through Gmail, Google s email service, are designed to steal passwords.

entry.title: Google commits millions to European news organizations
entry.summary:
BERLIN -- Google says it will give European publishers more than $162 million to help them adapt to the challenge of selling news online.

Google said in a statement Tuesday it is establishing the Digital News Initiative together with eight leading publishers, including the Financial Times and the Guardian.

Last year, Google blocked Spanish publishers' reports from more than 70 Google News international editions due to a new Spanish law requiring aggregators to pay to link content.

entry.title: Google launches portal to buy patents
entry.summary:
(Reuters) - Google Inc (GOOGL.O) said it would launch an experimental portal that allows interested patent holders to sell their patents to the company.

Patent holders can tell Google about the patents they're willing to sell and the expected price through the portal, the company said on its blog.

entry.title: Google executive killed in Mount Everest avalanche after quake
entry.summary: April 25 (Reuters) - Dan Fredinburg, a Google Inc executive based in California, was among those killed on Saturday in an avalanche on Mount Everest caused by a devastating earthquake in Nepal, the company said.

entry.title: Google executive among hundreds dead from Nepal quake
Google executive Dan Fredinburg among hundreds dead from Nepal earthquake
entry.summary:
Fredinburg, a Google executive who described himself as an adventurer, was among the hundreds who died in a massive earthquake that struck Nepal.

Lawrence You, the company's director of privacy, posted online that Fredinburg was in Nepal with three other Google employees climbing Mount Everest.

Fredinburg started at Google in 2007.

entry.title: Google lavishes chairman with $109 million pay package
entry.summary:
SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Google paid its billionaire Executive Chairman Eric Schmidt nearly $109 million last year while the company's stock slumped.

His total pay last year soared by more than five-fold from 2013 when his Google compensation was valued at $19.3 million.

entry.title: Google reports 12% rise in revenue
entry.summary: In the technology giant's financial results for the first quarter of 2015, Google reported total revenue of 17.3 billion dollars ( 11.4 billion), a 12% rise on the same period last year.

entry.title: Google posts mixed 1Q results amid new threats to company
entry.summary: Even as Google sows new fields, the company faces changes in how people find information and peruse digital content.

entry.title: Google posts mixed 1Q results amid new threats to company
entry.summary:
SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Google has been looking more vulnerable as a technological upheaval nibbles at its dominance in Internet search, while the company also deals with a potentially massive regulatory headache in Europe.

But those threats haven't done much to undercut Google's power or profits yet.

Google's first-quarter earnings rose 4 percent to $3.6 billion as the company's Internet-leading advertising network lifted revenue by 14 percent to $17.3 billion from the same time last year.

It marked the sixth consecutive quarter that Google's earnings have fallen below the analysts' targets that shape investors' expectations.

entry.title: Google wireless phone service challenges major carriers
entry.summary:
SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Google is trying to shake up the wireless phone industry with a low-priced service designed to pressure major carriers into making it more affordable for people to get online and use Google's services.

The service, called "Project Fi," debuted Wednesday, about two months after Google revealed its plans to expand its ever-growing empire into providing wireless connections for smartphones.

entry.title: Google shaking up search recommendations on smartphones
New Google formula to favor mobile-friendly websites
entry.summary: But new pecking order in Google's mobile search may relegate some sites to the back pages of the search results, even if their content is more relevant to a search request than other sites that happen to be easier to access on smartphones.

entry.title: Google to use ?mobile-friendly? browsing on mobile devices
entry.summary:
Although Google's new formula won't affect searches on desktop and laptop computers, it will have a huge influence on how and where people spend their money, given that more people are relying on their smartphones to compare products in stores and look for restaurants.

Here are a few things to know about what's happening and why Google is doing it.

To stay in Google's good graces, websites must be designed so they load quickly on mobile devices.

entry.title: Google embraces 'mobile-friendly' sites in search shake-up
entry.summary: Google has been urging websites to cater to mobile device for years, mainly because that is where people are increasingly searching for information.

entry.title: Google embraces 'mobile-friendly' sites in search shake-up
entry.summary: While most major merchants and big companies already have websites likely to meet Google's mobile standard, the new formula threatens to hurt millions of small businesses that haven't had the money or incentive to adapt their sites for smartphones.

entry.title: Google embraces 'mobile-friendly' sites in search shake-up
entry.summary:
SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Google is about to change the way its influential search engine recommends websites on smartphones and tablets in a shift that's expected to sway where millions of people shop, eat and find information.

The revised formula, scheduled to be released Tuesday, will favor websites that Google defines as "mobile-friendly."

Websites that don't fit the description will be demoted in Google's search results on smartphones and tablets while those meeting the criteria will be more likely to appear at the top of the rankings - a prized position that can translate into more visitors and money.

entry.title: Google embraces 'mobile-friendly' sites in search shake-up
entry.summary: That's why Google's new rating system is being billed by some search experts as "Mobile-geddon."

entry.title: EU alleges Google's abuses hurt consumers, innovation
entry.summary: For now at least, Europe's case is focused on Google's shopping comparison service, known as Google Shopping, which shows various products and prices when consumers make a search request indicating they are looking to buy something.

entry.title: EU alleges Google's abuses hurt consumers, innovation

Drawing upon a nearly five-year probe, the regulators filed a complaint alleging that Google has been improperly favoring its own shopping comparison service in its own search results.

But Google's shopping comparison service doesn't include all products in any category.

entry.title: EU alleges Google's abuses hurt consumers, innovation

entry.title: EU charges Google in Internet search anti-trust case
entry.summary:
She also said other probes into Google's business practices would continue.

"If the investigation confirmed our concerns, Google would have to face the legal consequences and change the way it does business in Europe."

The focus on the ranking of searches for shopping sites - Google has its own service called Google Shopping - did not address all complaints lodged with the Commission by competitors, large and small, in Europe and the United States, which say Google has hurt their business.

entry.title: EU Charges Google With Abusing Market Position

entry.title: European Union hits Google with official antitrust charges
entry.summary:
When it comes to comparative shopping, the EU said it found that "Google gives systematic favorable treatment" to its Google Shopping at the expense of others in its general search results.

Google has 10 weeks to respond to all the allegations.

entry.title: EU to accuse Google of illegally abusing search

entry.title: EU to announce antitrust moves against Google on Wednesday: papers

The EU can impose fines of up to 10 percent of global turnover, or more than $6 billion in penalties in Google's case.

An EU official said Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager would make an important announcement about Google on Wednesday, after the EU's executive holds its weekly meeting.

Separately, Vestager will launch an investigation into Google's Android mobile software business, the FT said.

entry.title: Reports: Google facing antitrust showdown in Europe
entry.summary:
European regulators are poised to file charges alleging Google abused its dominance in Internet search to thwart competition and innovation, according to reports published Tuesday.

An antitrust case against Google would be Europe's biggest since regulators wrangled with Microsoft.

entry.title: Judge rules against Mississippi attorney general over Google
entry.summary:
The judge wrote Google had a legitimate fear of Hood coercing it into giving up its First Amendment right to free speech because it feared prosecution, and that Hood's authority appeared to be overridden by federal law.

Hood said digital piracy, one of his allegations against Google, is a serious part of online crime.

entry.title: Google anti-trust foes see friend in new EU competition chief
entry.summary:
Danish politician Margrethe Vestager, who took over the EU competition portfolio in November, inherited an anti-trust complaint by more than a dozen companies against Google, left unresolved by her Spanish predecessor Joaquin Almunia.

In one sign of movement in recent weeks, the European Commission has asked some of the Google opponents to allow regulators to declassify some of the confidential data they submitted to justify their accusations, a step that would be necessary to present the data to Google for its response.

Google's camera cars that gather photos for its "Street View" function will start measuring methane emissions and natural gas leaks in some cities this year.

entry.title: Google says working to restore YouTube service in Turkey
entry.summary: FRANKFURT (Reuters) - Google (GOOGL.O) has seen reports that YouTube is blocked in Turkey and is working to restore its video-sharing service, a company spokesman said on Monday.

entry.title: Stock split could cost Google over $500 million
entry.summary:
Page, 42, and Brin, 41, have maintained control over Google since they started the company in a rented Silicon Valley garage in 1998.

To maintain the power to drive Google's direction, Page and Brin initially accumulated virtually all of the company's class "B'' shares, which have 10 votes for each "A'' share.

To settle a class-action lawsuit challenging the split, Google agreed to compensate "C'' shareholders if the average price of "C'' stock fell more than 1 percent below "A'' shares through the first year of trading.

entry.title: Stock split could cost Google more than $500 million
entry.summary:
The big spending is one reason Google's stock price is about 2 percent below where it stood at the end of 2013, while the Standard & Poor's 500 index has climbed 11 percent.

A year ago Thursday, Google split its stock to create a new category of "C" stock with no voting power that would allow more Google shares to be issued without undercutting Page and Brin.

Google argued there wouldn't be much difference between the price of "C" and "A" shares because Page and Brin held majority control anyway with the "B" shares.

entry.title: Stock split could cost Google over $500 million
entry.summary: Google declined to comment.

entry.title: Google fails to dismiss privacy lawsuit over Google Wallet
Google fails to dismiss privacy lawsuit over Google Wallet

A Google search page is reflected in sunglasses in this photo illustration taken in Brussels May 30, 2014.

She said Google raised the risk of identity theft by routinely sending information about Google Wallet users such as addresses and zip codes, phone numbers and email addresses to app developers.

Google Inc et al, U.S. District Court, Northern District of California, No.

China Internet authority denounces Google certificate rejection
entry.summary:
CNNIC, which plays a central role in administering China's Internet by allocating and certifying IP addresses and web domain names, urged Google to consider user rights and interests.

"The decision that Google has made is unacceptable and unintelligible," the agency said in a statement on its website.

That rendered connections between users and those websites vulnerable to 'man-in-the-middle' hacking attacks, Google said.

Microsoft Corp and Mozilla, which together with Google develop three of the world's most-used web browsers, also removed trust of those unauthorized certificates last week, following Google's post.

entry.title: China Internet authority denounces Google certificate rejection
entry.summary: That means that users of Google's Chrome, the world's top Internet browser, may get a warning when attempting to visit sites certified by CNNIC.

entry.title: Google flips out for April Fool's Day
entry.summary: Using its own Top Level Domain, all-comers were invited to visit com.google instead of the usual google.com.

entry.title: Google Maps turns into Pac-Man's chomping grounds
entry.summary:
SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - The virtual streets of Google Maps are being transformed into Pac-Man's chomping grounds in celebration of April Fools' Day.

Google added the option to convert its popular navigation service into the Pac-Man video game on Tuesday morning, around the same day the calendar turned to April 1 in Asia.

That ushered in a day when Google shows off its playful side by injecting more frivolity into its services.

The gag on Google Maps enables visitors to click on a Pac-Man symbol in the lower left of the screen to play the video game on whatever location is listed in the address bar.

entry.title: Google Maps turns into Pac-Man's chomping grounds
Google, Microsoft battle drives down prices for PCs, tablets
entry.summary:
Google has used the Chromebooks as a prod to bring down the prices of all PCs, something the company wanted to do because it has more opportunities to show the digital ads that bring in most of its revenue when more people can afford to buy an Internet-connected device.

"We cannot be happier that Microsoft is helping drive down the prices of PCs," said Caesar Sengupta, Google's vice president of product management for Chromebooks.

Google is releasing two $149 laptops in an effort to undercut Microsoft's Windows franchise and drive down already falling personal computer prices.

entry.title: Google, Microsoft battle drives down prices for PCs, tablets
Google, Microsoft battle drives down prices for PCs, tablets
entry.summary: Besides the $149 laptops, Google also is attacking Microsoft on other fronts.

entry.title: Google, Microsoft battle drives down prices for PCs, tablets
entry.summary:
SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Google is releasing its cheapest Chromebook laptops yet, two versions priced at $149 aimed at undercutting Microsoft's Windows franchise and gaining ground in even more classrooms.

Various PC manufacturers have been working with Google to design lightweight laptops running on the Chrome operating system since 2011.

The Chromebook has served a dual purpose for Google.

Later this spring, Google and Asus are releasing a hybrid Chromebook that can use used as either a laptop or tablet with a 10-inch screen.

The Chromebit's price hasn't been set, Google says it will cost less than $100.

entry.title: Google announces newer, cheaper Chromebooks

entry.title: Google users CAN sue internet giant in British courts over its tracking of their browsing
entry.summary: The claimants, known as Safari Users Against Google's Secret Tracking, all used Apple's Safari browser and have accused Google of bypassing security settings in order to track their online browsing and target them with adverts.

entry.title: If you use Safari on a Mac, iPhone or iPad in the UK you've won the right to SUE Google
entry.summary:
A High Court judge previously rejected an attempt by Google to block the litigation, and today three appeal judges upheld his decision, saying the claims "raise serious issues which merit a trial".

Jonathan Hawker represents the Google Action Group, a not-for-profit company set up to manage claims against the internet giant for breach of privacy through the Safari workaround.

"We urge all Safari users to join us in this battle to hold Google to account for its actions in the only way it understands."

entry.title: Google loses appeal bid over suing
entry.summary:
Google has lost a Court of Appeal bid to prevent British consumers having the right to sue it in the UK.

They say Google's ''clandestine'' tracking and collation of internet usage between summer 2011 and early 2012 led to distress and embarrassment among UK users.

They accuse Google of collecting private information without their knowledge and consent by the use of "cookies" - a small string of text saved on the user's device.

entry.title: Google CFO Gets $70 Million Pay Package
Google's new CFO gets $70 million for defecting from Morgan Stanley
entry.summary:
Google's new chief financial officer, Ruth Porat, is being paid more than $70 million for defecting from the same job at investment bank Morgan Stanley.

Google Inc. also is giving Porat a $5 million signing bonus to supplement her starting salary of $650,000.

entry.title: Google to pay new CFO annual base salary of US$650,000
entry.summary: Porat, who will join Google on May 26, will also get a new hire grant of $25 million through restricted stock units and a $40 million biennial grant in 2016, the company said in a regulatory filing on Thursday.

entry.title: Google to pay new CFO annual base salary of $650,000

entry.title: Salt Lake City will soon offer Google's high-speed Internet
entry.summary:
Google Fiber spokesman Devin Baer said the company plans to start construction for the network after several months of planning with city officials.

Google chose Salt Lake City because it has a "thriving tech community" and is a natural extension from Provo, he said.

entry.title: Salt Lake City will soon offer Google's high-speed Internet
entry.summary:
SALT LAKE CITY (AP) - Salt Lake City will soon join a handful of U.S. cities in offering high-speed internet service through Google Fiber.

Google offers three levels of service to customers who pay the $30 activation fee in Provo, one of the first cities selected for the project.

Google Fiber will not provide the number of households connected to its service, but said Baer said things in Provo have been "really great."

Porat will replace 52-year-old Patrick Pichette, who announced plans to retire from Google about two weeks ago.

entry.title: Morgan Stanley CFO leaves for same position at Google

Morgan Stanley chief financial officer Ruth Porat is leaving the bank to join Google Inc. in the same position, the companies said on Tuesday.

Porat will join Google on May 26, the company said in a blog post.

Towns and cities in Spain are being renamed on Google Maps after their former incarnations as Islamic kingdoms almost 10 centuries ago.

Google encourages users to moderate incorrect material and bars those found to have acted maliciously or to have given wrong information three times.

It will run Google Inc.'s Android Wear system, which is already used in smartwatches by Motorola, Sony, LG and others.

Tag Heuer, Google and Intel made the announcement at Baselworld, a watch and jewelry trade show in Switzerland.

entry.title: Google app store gets more oversight
entry.summary:
The change brings Google Play, a bazaar for digital games, social media apps and entertainment software, closer to Apple Inc's tightly controlled App Store.

Google had only used automated technology for screening at the time of submission.

The new process will not create bottlenecks, Google said in a post, promising that approved apps will become available on Google Play within "a matter of hours" after submission.

Developers must answer special questionnaires about their apps to help independent ratings organizations assign age-based ratings, Google said.

"We know that people in different countries have different ideas about what content is appropriate for kids, teens and adults, so today's announcement will help developers better label their apps for the right audience," Google said in the blog post.

As of May, apps submitted without the questionnaire will not be published in Google Play, and existing apps that do not seek a rating could be blocked in certain markets or for certain users, Google said.

Google, whose Android software runs most of the world's smartphones, and Apple each manage online hubs with more than one million apps ranging from calendars to video games.

entry.title: US at odds with Google on computer search-warrant proposal
entry.summary: Another critic, Google, says the proposal "raises a number of monumental and highly complex constitutional, legal and geopolitical concerns that should be left for Congress to decide."

entry.title: It's a bird! It's a plane! Google balloon crash alarms town
entry.summary:
But the crash of one of Google's "Loon" balloons for relaying Internet service was enough to have security forces summoned to a mountain township in central Mexico.

They found one of the huge, jellyfish-shaped balloons that Google is using to carry antennas to deliver online access in remote areas.

Veracruz authorities have notified Google to come pick up the remains of the balloon and the transmission equipment.

entry.title: 'FREAK attack' leaves millions of Apple and Google users vulnerable to hackers
entry.summary: Millions of people may have been left vulnerable to hackers while surfing the web on Apple and Google devices, thanks to a newly discovered security flaw known as "FREAK attack."

entry.title: Google selling wireless plans to get more people online
entry.summary:
Google wants more people to get online so they can search around and click on its ads.

The move into the wireless market mirrors what Google has been trying to do for hard-wired Internet access at home.

Pichai downplayed the competitive threat that Google might pose.

entry.title: Google, Facebook update contrasting plans to connect world
entry.summary: And while Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Google Vice President Sundar Pichai say they might like to collaborate more, they are taking very different approaches to getting the world connected.

entry.title: Google, Facebook update contrasting plans to connect world
entry.summary:
Google and Facebook want more people online, searching around and clicking on ads.

Earlier, Pichai announced Google's plans to start testing the use of solar-powered drone aircraft as "floating cell towers" that could bring coverage to remote areas or even disaster zones.

He also said that Google's "Project Loon" - which uses high-altitude air balloons to provide coverage for rural areas - had advanced to the point that the balloons are expected to be ready in two years.

entry.title: Judge puts Mississippi AG's investigation of Google on hold
Google says it plans to offer cellular service
entry.summary:
Google will soon be offering cellular network plans.

Vice-President Sundar Pichai says Google, the leading internet search engine and mobile software provider, is working with unnamed network operators on developing a cellular plan.

entry.title: Judge puts AG's attempt to investigate Google on hold
entry.summary:
(AP) - The Mississippi attorney general's attempt to investigate Google is on hold for at least four more months.

Wingate said that, at this point, Google has the stronger argument.

However, Hood says he wants to investigate Google's own conduct.

entry.title: Google to offer own cellular network plan
entry.summary:
Pichai compared Google's latest move to its decision to launch its own line of Nexus smartphones, which he said Google uses not to compete with other smartphone makers, but to introduce innovations in mobile hardware.

Finding a way to provide a "seamless" Internet connection when a device moves from Wi-Fi to cellular coverage as one example of goals Google would like to target, Pichai said.

He also noted that Google is also working on "Android Pay," a mobile payment system similar to "Apple Pay," that will work across all Android-powered devices.

Google plans to be a "mobile virtual network operator," which means it will lease space on an existing system.

Pichai didn't name Google's wireless partners, but previous media reports have identified Sprint Corp. and T-Mobile US Inc. Neither of those carriers has confirmed those plans yet.

If Google's entry into the wireless market is successful, the company may even try to take over Sprint or T-Mobile, Menezes said.

entry.title: Google to offer own cellular network plan
Next Google Maps adventure: Soaring through Amazon jungle
entry.summary:
SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - For its next technological trick, Google will show you what it's like to zip through trees in the Amazon jungle.

Google is renowned for going out on a technological limb, but even this project made the company nervous at first, said Karin Tuxen-Bettman, who oversees Google's Street View partnerships.

"One of the things that I love about working at Google is that if a partner comes to us with a crazy idea, we will probably try it," Tuxen-Bettman said.

Since Google developed the Trekker camera in 2012, the device has been dispatched on other unusual journeys.

entry.title: French minister meets with Google, Facebook, Twitter

entry.title: French minister meets with Google, Facebook, Twitter
entry.summary: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - The French interior minister said Friday he asked Google, Facebook and Twitter to work directly with French officials during investigations and to immediately remove terrorist propaganda when authorities alert them to it.
